choices.text: Corticosteroids (CS) + IMiD (e.g., lenalidomide)
CS + proteasome inhibitor (e.g., bortezomib) + daratumumab
Autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma and no significant comorbidities is being evaluated for treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CS + proteasome inhibitor (e.g., bortezomib) + daratumumab

 

The combination of corticosteroids (CS), an immunomodulatory drug (IMiD) like lenalidomide or pomalidomide, a proteasome inhibitor like bortezomib or carfilzomib, and daratumumab (anti-CD38 monoclonal antibody) is the standard initial therapy for transplant-eligible patients with multiple myeloma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Daratumumab monotherapy: While daratumumab is a potent anti-CD38 monoclonal antibody with significant efficacy in multiple myeloma, it is not typically used as a single agent in the initial treatment of newly diagnosed patients. It is usually combined with other drugs to achieve a more robust response.

 

Option B. Corticosteroids (CS) + IMiD (e.g., lenalidomide): This combination can be effective, but it is not the standard of care for transplant-eligible patients. Adding a proteasome inhibitor (PI) to this regimen has been shown to improve response rates and survival.

 

Option D. Autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT): HSCT is a consolidation therapy option for multiple myeloma patients after initial induction therapy. It is not the first-line treatment, but it is often considered for transplant-eligible patients who achieve a good response to induction therapy.

 

Educational objective:

 

The standard initial therapy for multiple myeloma involves a combination of drugs targeting different pathways to maximize efficacy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with stage IV CHL, an albumin of 3.5 g/dL, hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, and a WBC count of 16,000/µL with 500 lymphocytes/µL. According to the IPS, how many risk factors does he have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4

 

Option C:

 

The patient has the following risk factors:

 

  • Albumin < 4 g/dL
  • Hemoglobin < 10.5 g/dL
  • Stage IV disease
  • Lymphocytes < 600/µL

 

Educational objective:

 

The IPS identifies patients with a higher risk of treatment failure and helps guide therapy decisions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with a rapidly enlarging jaw mass and systemic B symptoms. Biopsy reveals medium-sized lymphoid cells with a starry sky pattern. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most likely associated with this lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) t(8;14)

 

Option C:

 

The t(8;14) translocation is the hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma. It results in the overexpression of the MYC oncogene, leading to aggressive proliferation of B cells. The other translocations are associated with different lymphomas (A & D: Mantle Cell Lymphoma, B: Follicular Lymphoma).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(11;14): This translocation is characteristic of Mantle Cell Lymphoma. It involves the cyclin D1 gene and leads to increased cell cycle progression.

 

Option B. t(14;18): This translocation is associated with Follicular Lymphoma. It involves the BCL2 gene, which inhibits apoptosis and promotes cell survival.

 

Option D. t(11;18): This translocation is also associated with Mantle Cell Lymphoma, like option A.

 

Educational objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell lymphoma characterized by a specific translocation, t(8;14).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with abdominal pain and a palpable mass. Biopsy reveals Burkitt's lymphoma. Which of the following infectious agents is most likely associated with this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

 

Option A:

 

EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic regions. The other infectious agents are not directly linked to Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV): While HIV infection increases the risk of various lymphomas, including Burkitt's lymphoma, it is not the most common infectious agent directly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C virus (HCV): HCV is primarily associated with liver disease and certain types of lymphoma, but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori): H. pylori is a bacterium that infects the stomach and is associated with gastric cancer and lymphoma of the stomach (MALT lymphoma), but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

EBV plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

choices.text: MYC translocation with BCL2 or BCL6 rearrangement
BCL2 translocation with BCL6 rearrangement

questions.text: Which genetic abnormality defines double-hit lymphoma (DHL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MYC translocation with BCL2 or BCL6 rearrangement

 

Option B:

 

DHL is characterized by a combination of MYC translocation (usually t(8;14)) and a rearrangement of either BCL2 (t(14;18)) or BCL6. This results in the overexpression of multiple oncogenes, leading to aggressive lymphoma behavior.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(14;18) with MYC overexpression: While t(14;18) is associated with BCL2 overexpression and is seen in follicular lymphoma, it alone does not define DHL. DHL requires the additional presence of a MYC translocation.

 

Option C. BCL2 translocation with BCL6 rearrangement: This combination of rearrangements is not characteristic of DHL. DHL specifically requires a MYC translocation.

 

Option D. Trisomy 12 with BCL6 rearrangement: Trisomy 12 is associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), and while BCL6 rearrangement can occur in various lymphomas, this combination does not define DHL.

 

Educational objective:

 

The combined dysregulation of MYC and BCL2/BCL6 is the defining feature of DHL.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with painless, slowly enlarging lymph nodes in her neck and axillae. Lymph node biopsy reveals small, cleaved lymphocytes with a follicular pattern. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most commonly associated with this type of lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) t(14;18)

 

Option C:

 

The t(14;18) translocation is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma (FL). It results in overexpression of the BCL2 gene, which inhibits apoptosis and promotes cell survival.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(8;14): This translocation is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. It leads to overexpression of the MYC oncogene, promoting cell growth and proliferation.

 

Option B. t(11;14): This translocation is associated with mantle cell lymphoma. It leads to overexpression of cyclin D1, which regulates the cell cycle.

 

Option D. t(15;17): This translocation is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). It leads to the fusion of the PML and RARA genes, disrupting normal cell differentiation.

 

Educational objective:

 

t(14;18) is a diagnostic feature of FL and contributes to its indolent nature.

choices.text: R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone)
HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is NOT typically used as a first-line treatment for symptomatic follicular lymphoma (FL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

 

Option D:

 

HyperCVAD is a more intensive regimen typically used for aggressive lymphomas. R-CHOP, R-CVP, and BR are more common first-line options for FL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone): This is a widely used and effective first-line treatment for FL. It combines the monoclonal antibody rituximab with a standard chemotherapy regimen (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone).

 

Option B. R-CVP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Prednisone): This is another commonly used first-line regimen for FL, particularly in older or less fit patients. It is similar to R-CHOP but uses vincristine instead of doxorubicin, which is associated with less cardiotoxicity.

 

Option C. Bendamustine-rituximab (BR): This is a well-tolerated and effective regimen that has gained popularity as a first-line treatment for FL, especially in patients who may not tolerate the anthracycline component of R-CHOP.

 

Educational objective:

 

FL is typically treated with less intensive chemotherapy regimens compared to aggressive lymphomas.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows "hairy cells" with cytoplasmic projections. Which of the following markers is most specific for the diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia (HCL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CD103

 

Option C:

 

CD103 is a highly specific marker for hairy cell leukemia. While CD19 and CD20 are B-cell markers expressed in HCL, they are not specific. CD30 is associated with Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CD19: This is a B-cell marker that is expressed in HCL, but it is not specific to HCL. It is also found on other B-cell malignancies.

 

Option B. CD20: Similar to CD19, this is a B-cell marker present in HCL but not specific to it.

 

Option D. CD30: This marker is primarily associated with classical Hodgkin lymphoma and anaplastic large cell lymphoma. It is not expressed in HCL.

 

Educational objective:

 

CD103 is a key diagnostic marker for hairy cell leukemia

choices.text: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/Small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL)

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with fatigue and mild lymphadenopathy. Blood tests reveal lymphocytosis with smudge cells on peripheral smear. Flow cytometry shows CD5 and CD23 positivity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/Small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL)

 

Option C:

 

The presence of lymphocytosis with smudge cells and CD5/CD23 positivity is characteristic of CLL/SLL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the proliferation of immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow and blood. It does not typically present with smudge cells or CD5/CD23 positivity.

 

Option B. Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL): MCL is a type of B-cell lymphoma with a characteristic t(11;14) translocation. While it can present with lymphocytosis, it typically lacks smudge cells and does not express CD23.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma (HL): HL is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, which are large, atypical cells not seen in CLL/SLL. HL typically does not present with smudge cells or a predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

Educational objective:

 

CLL/SLL is a B-cell neoplasm characterized by the accumulation of small, mature lymphocytes with specific immunophenotypic markers.

questions.text: Which of the following is a potential adverse effect of venetoclax, a BCL2 inhibitor used in CLL/SLL treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor lysis syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a serious complication of rapid tumor cell breakdown and can occur with venetoclax therapy. The other options are not typical adverse effects of venetoclax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Atrial fibrillation: While cardiac arrhythmias can be a side effect of some cancer therapies, atrial fibrillation is not a common side effect specifically associated with venetoclax.

 

Option C. Diarrhea: Diarrhea is a common side effect of many chemotherapies but is not a characteristic side effect of venetoclax.

 

Option D. Peripheral neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy (damage to peripheral nerves causing numbness, tingling, or pain) can be a side effect of certain chemotherapy agents, but it is not typically associated with venetoclax.

 

Educational objective:

 

Monitoring for and preventing TLS is crucial when initiating venetoclax therapy in CLL/SLL.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is associated with a poor prognosis in CLL/SLL?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Del(17p)

 

Option B:

 

Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 17 (del(17p)) leads to loss of the TP53 tumor suppressor gene, resulting in resistance to chemotherapy and a poorer prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Del(13q): This is the most common genetic abnormality in CLL/SLL and is associated with a favorable prognosis. It typically involves deletion of the microRNA genes miR-15a and miR-16-1, which regulate B-cell survival.

 

Option C. Mutated IgVH genes: CLL/SLL cases with mutated IgVH genes generally have a more indolent course and better prognosis compared to those with unmutated IgVH genes.

 

Option D. Trisomy 12: This is an intermediate-risk genetic abnormality in CLL/SLL, with a prognosis between that of del(13q) and del(17p). It can be associated with atypical morphology and increased proliferative activity.

 

Educational objective:

 

del(17p) is a high-risk genetic abnormality in CLL/SLL.

choices.text: Higher response rates in certain patient subgroups

questions.text: Which of the following is a potential advantage of targeted therapies like BTK inhibitors or BCL2 inhibitors over traditional chemotherapy in CLL/SLL treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Targeted therapies like BTK inhibitors (e.g., ibrutinib) and BCL2 inhibitors (e.g., venetoclax) offer several advantages over traditional chemotherapy, including a lower risk of infection, improved tolerability, and higher response rates in certain patient populations.

 

Educational objective:

 

Targeted therapies have revolutionized the treatment landscape for CLL/SLL, offering improved outcomes and reduced toxicity compared to traditional chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Japan presents with hypercalcemia, lytic bone lesions, and skin rash. Peripheral blood smear reveals atypical lymphocytes with "cloverleaf" nuclei. Which of the following viruses is most likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1)

 

Option B:

 

HTLV-1 infection is strongly associated with the development of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL). The presence of hypercalcemia, lytic bone lesions, skin rash, and atypical lymphocytes with "cloverleaf" nuclei are classic findings in ATLL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): EBV is associated with other lymphoid malignancies, such as Burkitt lymphoma and Hodgkin lymphoma, but not typically with ATLL.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): While HIV increases the risk of various malignancies, including lymphomas, it is not the primary cause of ATLL.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): CMV is a common virus that usually causes mild or asymptomatic infections. It is not linked to the development of ATLL.

 

Educational objective:

 

HTLV-1 infection is a crucial risk factor for ATLL, particularly in endemic regions like Japan and the Caribbean.

choices.text: Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified (PTCL-NOS)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of breast implants presents with a rapidly enlarging axillary lymph node. Excisional biopsy reveals large atypical cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical staining shows strong expression of CD30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL)

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation (breast implants, rapidly enlarging lymph node), morphology (large atypical cells, horseshoe-shaped nuclei), and CD30 expression are characteristic of ALCL. While CD30 is also expressed in HL, the morphology of RS cells is different.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma (HL): While HL can express CD30, it lacks the characteristic hallmark cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei seen in ALCL. RS cells are usually larger and have a bilobed or multi-lobed nucleus.

 

Option B. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL): DLBCL is a B-cell lymphoma and would not express CD30. The cells in DLBCL are also not typically described as having horseshoe-shaped nuclei.

 

Option D. Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified (PTCL-NOS): PTCL-NOS is a heterogeneous group of T-cell lymphomas. While it can share some features with ALCL, it does not have the specific hallmark cells or the same association with breast implants.

 

Educational objective:

 

ALCL is a T-cell lymphoma characterized by large atypical cells, CD30 expression, and potential association with breast implants.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) presents with new-onset renal insufficiency. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism underlying his renal dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Light chain cast nephropathy

 

In multiple myeloma, light chains produced by the clonal plasma cells can precipitate in the renal tubules, leading to light chain cast nephropathy and renal insufficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glomerulonephritis: Glomerulonephritis is an inflammation of the glomeruli, the tiny filters in the kidneys. While it can cause renal insufficiency, it's not the most common mechanism in patients with MM or MGUS.

 

Option B. Tubulointerstitial nephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the tubules and the surrounding tissue in the kidneys. It can be caused by medications or infections but is less likely in the context of MGUS progressing to MM.

 

Option D. Obstructive uropathy: This refers to a blockage of the urinary tract, which can lead to kidney damage. While it's possible, it's less likely to be the primary cause of renal insufficiency in a patient with MM or MGUS.

 

Educational objective:

 

The progression of MGUS to multiple myeloma often leads to the production of excess light chains, which can cause kidney damage through light chain cast nephropathy. It's a crucial consideration in the management of these patients.

choices.text: >60% clonal bone marrow plasma cells
≥2 focal lesions (>5mm) on whole-body MRI

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the SLIM criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL

 

Option D:

 

Elevated serum creatinine is part of the CRAB criteria, indicating renal impairment. SLIM criteria do not include renal function assessment.

 

Educational objective:

 

The SLIM criteria focus on biomarkers indicating clonal plasma cell expansion and disease burden, while the CRAB criteria assess end-organ damage.

questions.text: Which of the following bone marrow plasma cell (BMPC) percentages would NOT meet the criteria for myeloma-defining events (MDE)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 15%

 

MDE require either ≥60% clonal BMPCs (SLIM criteria) or a biopsy-proven plasmacytoma (regardless of BMPC percentage).

 

Educational objective:

 

MDEs can be identified by a significant clonal plasma cell burden in the bone marrow or the presence of a plasmacytoma.

choices.text: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of worsening fatigue, back pain, and unintentional weight loss. On examination, he is pale and has point tenderness over the lumbar spine. Laboratory findings reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated creatinine. A skeletal survey shows multiple lytic lesions in the spine and pelvis. Serum electrophoresis was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma (MM)

 

The patient's presentation with fatigue, bone pain, weight loss, anemia, hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency (elevated creatinine), and lytic bone lesions strongly suggests multiple myeloma. These findings fulfill the CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions) which are characteristic of MM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS): MGUS is a benign condition where a small amount of monoclonal protein (M-protein) is present in the blood, but there are no symptoms or signs of end-organ damage (CRAB criteria). The patient in this scenario clearly has CRAB criteria, ruling out MGUS.

 

Option B. Smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM): SMM is a precursor to multiple myeloma and is characterized by a higher level of M-protein or bone marrow plasma cells than MGUS, but still no CRAB criteria. This patient's presentation with anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal insufficiency indicates organ damage, making SMM less likely.

 

Option D. Waldenström macroglobulinemia (WM): WM is a type of lymphoma where malignant B cells produce excessive IgM antibodies. While it can present with some similar features to multiple myeloma (like fatigue and anemia), it typically doesn't cause bone pain, hypercalcemia, or lytic bone lesions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy that can present with various symptoms, including bone pain, anemia, renal insufficiency, and hypercalcemia. The presence of CRAB criteria, along with lytic bone lesions and monoclonal protein in the serum or urine, are key diagnostic features.

choices.text: Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and pruritus. Excisional biopsy of a lymph node reveals Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells positive for CD15 and CD30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma (CHL)

 

Option A:

 

The presence of classical Reed-Sternberg cells positive for CD15 and CD30 is pathognomonic for CHL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL): This subtype is characterized by "popcorn" cells, which are negative for CD15 and CD30.

 

Option C. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and Option D. Follicular lymphoma (FL): These are non-Hodgkin lymphomas with different histopathological features.

 

Educational objective:

 

CHL is diagnosed based on the presence of classic RS cells positive for CD15 and CD30.

questions.text: Which of the following markers is typically positive in NLPHL but negative in CHL?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CD20

 

Option B:

 

"Popcorn" cells in NLPHL express CD20, while classic RS cells in cHL are negative for CD20.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CD15: This marker is often positive in CHL, particularly in the Reed-Sternberg cells. It may be positive in NLPHL but is not a defining characteristic.

 

Option C. CD30: This marker is typically positive in CHL, especially in the Reed-Sternberg cells. It is usually negative in NLPHL.

 

Option D. CD45: This marker is a general leukocyte marker and is expressed in both CHL and NLPHL, but it is not helpful in differentiating between the two.

 

Educational objective:

 

CD20 expression can help differentiate between CHL and NLPHL.

choices.text: R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone)
R-EPOCH (Rituximab, Etoposide, Prednisone, Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin)
HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a rapidly enlarging cervical lymph node and complains of fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. A lymph node biopsy confirms the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Which of the following treatment regimens is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone)

 

Option A:

 

R-CHOP: This is the standard first-line treatment for most patients with DLBCL, including the elderly. It combines the monoclonal antibody rituximab with a multi-agent chemotherapy regimen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. R-EPOCH (Rituximab, Etoposide, Prednisone, Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin): This is a more intensive regimen typically reserved for younger patients with high-risk disease or certain subtypes of DLBCL. It may not be suitable Option for older patients due to increased toxicity.

 

Option C. HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine): This is another intensive regimen often used in specific subtypes of aggressive lymphoma or for relapsed/refractory disease. It is not the standard first-line treatment for DLBCL.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy alone: While radiotherapy may be used in certain situations (e.g., localized disease), it is not sufficient as the sole treatment for most cases of DLBCL.

 

Educational objective:

 

R-CHOP is the standard first-line treatment for most newly diagnosed patients with DLBCL, including the elderly.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with abdominal discomfort, fatigue, and weight loss. Endoscopy reveals multiple gastric ulcers. Biopsy shows small to medium-sized lymphoid cells with CD5 expression but lacking CD23. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most characteristic of this lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) t(11;14)

 

Option C:

 

t(11;14) is the hallmark translocation of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). It leads to overexpression of cyclin D1 (CCND1), driving cell cycle progression and promoting tumorigenesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(14;18): This translocation is characteristic of follicular lymphoma, not mantle cell lymphoma. It involves the BCL2 gene, which inhibits apoptosis.

 

Option B. t(8;14): This translocation is the hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma. It leads to overexpression of the MYC oncogene, which promotes cell growth and proliferation.

 

Option D. t(15;17): This translocation is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a type of acute myeloid leukemia. It involves the PML and RARA genes.

 

Educational objective:

 

t(11;14) is a diagnostic feature of MCL and is associated with cyclin D1 overexpression.

choices.text: R-CHOP (Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, Prednisone)
HyperCVAD (Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Doxorubicin, Dexamethasone alternating with Methotrexate and Cytarabine)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a standard treatment option for mantle cell lymphoma (MCL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ABVD (Adriamycin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine)

 

Option D:

 

ABVD is a standard regimen for Hodgkin lymphoma but not typically used for MCL. R-CHOP, BR, and HyperCVAD are among the treatment options for MCL.

 

Educational objective:

 

Treatment for MCL involves different regimens than those used for Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most frequently associated with extranodal marginal zone lymphoma (ENMZL) of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) t(11;18)

 

Option B:

 

The t(11;18) translocation is the most common genetic abnormality in gastric MALT lymphoma, a subtype of ENMZL. It results in the fusion of the API2 and MALT1 genes, leading to activation of NF-KB signaling and promoting lymphomagenesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(8;14): This translocation is the hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma, a highly aggressive B-cell lymphoma. It leads to the overexpression of the MYC oncogene.

 

Option C. t(14;18): This translocation is characteristic of follicular lymphoma, another type of B-cell lymphoma. It involves the BCL2 gene, which inhibits apoptosis.

 

Option D. t(11;14): This translocation is the hallmark of mantle cell lymphoma, a type of B-cell lymphoma. It leads to overexpression of cyclin D1, promoting cell cycle progression.

 

Educational objective:

 

The t(11;18) translocation is a characteristic feature of MALT lymphoma and can guide treatment decisions, as cases with this translocation may not respond to H. pylori eradication alone.

questions.text: Which of the following infectious agents is most commonly associated with gastric MALT lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Helicobacter pylori

 

Option B:

 

Helicobacter pylori infection is strongly associated with gastric MALT lymphoma. Eradication of H. pylori can often lead to remission of the lymphoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): EBV is associated with several types of lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma and Hodgkin lymphoma, but not typically with gastric MALT lymphoma.

 

Option C. Chlamydia psittaci: This bacterium is associated with psittacosis (parrot fever) and can sometimes cause conjunctivitis. It is not linked to the development of gastric MALT lymphoma.

 

Option D. Borrelia burgdorferi: This bacterium is the causative agent of Lyme disease and is sometimes associated with cutaneous (skin) MALT lymphoma, but not gastric MALT lymphoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

H. pylori infection is a significant risk factor for developing gastric MALT lymphoma.

choices.text: Positive tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain
Increased serum uric acid levels

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings is characteristic of hairy cell leukemia (HCL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain

 

Option A:

 

The TRAP stain is a classic cytochemical test that is positive in hairy cells of HCL. The other options are not characteristic of HCL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Positive myeloperoxidase (MPO) stain: MPO is an enzyme found in myeloid cells (neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes) and is used to diagnose myeloid leukemias. It is not typically positive in HCL.

 

Option C. Increased serum uric acid levels: While elevated uric acid levels can be seen in various hematologic malignancies due to increased cell turnover, it is not a specific finding for HCL.

 

Option D. BCR-ABL1 fusion gene: This genetic abnormality is the hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and is not associated with HCL.

 

Educational objective:

 

A positive TRAP stain is a useful diagnostic clue for hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a persistent itchy, scaly rash on his trunk that has progressed over several months. Skin biopsy reveals epidermotropic lymphoid infiltrates with haloed lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mycosis fungoides (MF)

 

Option C:

 

The characteristic skin lesions, histopathological findings of epidermotropic lymphoid infiltrates with haloed lymphocytes, and progressive course are consistent with MF.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Psoriasis: Psoriasis can present with scaly plaques, but it usually has a well-demarcated border and lacks the characteristic epidermotropic lymphoid infiltrate with haloed lymphocytes seen in MF.

 

Option B. Atopic dermatitis: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and scaly rashes. However, it does not typically present with epidermotropic lymphoid infiltrates or haloed lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Sézary syndrome: Sézary syndrome is an advanced form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) characterized by erythroderma (widespread redness of the skin), circulating atypical T cells (Sézary cells), and generalized lymphadenopathy. While it can present with similar skin findings to MF, the widespread involvement and presence of Sézary cells in the blood distinguish it from early-stage MF.

 

Educational objective:

 

MF is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) and presents with a variety of skin manifestations.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with generalized erythroderma (redness of the skin), intense pruritus, and lymphadenopathy. Peripheral blood smear reveals atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sézary syndrome (SS)

 

Option D:

 

The combination of erythroderma, pruritus, lymphadenopathy, and atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei in the blood strongly suggests Sézary syndrome (SS), a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atopic dermatitis: While atopic dermatitis can cause itchy skin, it usually presents with localized patches of dry, scaly skin and does not typically cause erythroderma or lymphadenopathy. It also doesn't have the characteristic cerebriform nuclei seen in SS.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis can also cause itchy, scaly skin, but the plaques are usually well-demarcated and silvery. It does not typically progress to erythroderma or involve lymph nodes. Again, the cerebriform nuclei are not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides (MF): MF is another type of CTCL and can share some skin features with SS. However, it usually progresses more slowly and doesn't always present with erythroderma. In the early stages of MF, the atypical lymphocytes are typically confined to the skin, not circulating in the blood.

 

Educational objective:

 

SS is characterized by erythroderma, circulating Sézary cells, and lymphadenopathy.

choices.text: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

questions.text: A 65-year-old asymptomatic man undergoes routine blood tests, which reveal a serum M-protein level of 2.5 g/dL. Urine protein electrophoresis is negative. Bone marrow biopsy shows <10% clonal plasma cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

 

Option C:

 

MGUS is characterized by: * Serum M-protein <3 g/dL * Bone marrow plasma cells <10% * Absence of end-organ damage (CRAB criteria)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma would present with a higher M-protein level, a greater percentage of plasma cells in the bone marrow, and evidence of end-organ damage.

 

Option B. Waldenström macroglobulinemia: This is characterized by the overproduction of IgM antibodies, resulting in a high serum M-protein level. It also often presents with symptoms like hyperviscosity syndrome.

 

Option D. Smoldering multiple myeloma: This is a precursor to multiple myeloma with a higher M-protein level (>3 g/dL) and/or bone marrow plasma cells (10-60%) but no end-organ damage.

 

Educational objective:

 

MGUS is a common, premalignant condition that requires monitoring for progression to multiple myeloma.

questions.text: What is the approximate annual risk of progression of SMM to multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10%

 

Option B:

 

The average annual risk of progression of SMM to MM is approximately 10%. However, this risk can vary depending on individual risk factors and the presence of high-risk features.

 

Educational objective:

 

SMM has a significant risk of progression to MM, especially in the first few years after diagnosis.

choices.text: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, bone pain, and elevated serum creatinine. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an M-spike, and bone marrow biopsy shows 30% plasma cells. Skeletal survey reveals multiple lytic lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma (MM)

 

The presence of bone pain, elevated creatinine (indicating renal insufficiency), lytic bone lesions, and >10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow are consistent with multiple myeloma. This fulfills the CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions) necessary for a diagnosis of MM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS): MGUS is a benign condition characterized by a small M-spike and low levels of plasma cells in the bone marrow (<10%). Crucially, MGUS patients do not have end-organ damage (CRAB criteria).

 

Option B. Smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM): SMM is an intermediate stage between MGUS and multiple myeloma. While it has a higher risk of progression to myeloma, SMM patients typically lack the CRAB criteria that define multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Waldenström's macroglobulinemia (WM): WM is a type of lymphoma characterized by the overproduction of IgM antibodies. While it can share some features with multiple myeloma (like an M-spike), the clinical presentation and bone marrow findings are different. WM typically does not cause lytic bone lesions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by the presence of CRAB criteria, which distinguish it from MGUS and SMM.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a type of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy approved for multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brexucabtagene autoleucel (Tecartus)

 

Option D:

 

Brexucabtagene autoleucel (Tecartus): This CAR T-cell therapy targets CD19, a protein found on B cells. It is approved for the treatment of adult patients with relapsed or refractory mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cilta-cel (Carvykti): This CAR T-cell therapy targets the B-cell maturation antigen (BCMA) on myeloma cells. It is FDA-approved for adult patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma after at least four prior lines of therapy.

 

Option B. Ide-cel (Abecma): This is another BCMA-directed CAR T-cell therapy approved for adult patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma after at least four prior lines of therapy. It was the first CAR T-cell therapy approved for myeloma.

 

Option C. Abecma: This is the same therapy as Ide-cel.

 

Educational objective:

 

CAR T-cell therapy is a promising new treatment option for relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma has a serum β2-microglobulin (β2m) level of 2.8 mg/L and serum albumin of 3.8 g/dL. Based on the ISS, what is this patient's stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stage I

 

Option A:

 

The ISS categorizes multiple myeloma based on β2m and albumin levels. This patient's β2m is <3.5 mg/L and albumin is ≥3.5 g/dL, which corresponds to Stage I, associated with the best prognosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

ISS stage is a significant prognostic indicator in multiple myeloma.

choices.text: The patient has standard-risk myeloma and a good prognosis.
The patient has high-risk myeloma and a poor prognosis.
The t(14;16) translocation is not a significant prognostic factor in multiple myeloma.
The patient requires immediate allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: A patient with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma has a bone marrow biopsy revealing a t(14;16) translocation. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The patient has high-risk myeloma and a poor prognosis.

 

Option B:

 

The t(14;16) translocation is a high-risk cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma, associated with aggressive disease and a shorter survival. High risk features: t(4;14), t(14;16), t(14;20), del17p13, +1q, LDH ≥ 2x, PCL

 

Educational objective:

 

Identifying high-risk cytogenetic features in multiple myeloma is crucial for risk stratification and treatment decisions.

choices.text: Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS)

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and blurred vision. Laboratory findings show elevated IgM levels and anemia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals lymphoid cells with plasmacytic differentiation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Waldenström Macroglobulinemia (WM)

 

Option B:

 

The patient's age, symptoms of hyperviscosity (blurred vision), elevated IgM, and bone marrow findings are highly suggestive of WM. MM is less likely due to the absence of lytic lesions and hypercalcemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple Myeloma (MM): While MM can cause fatigue, weight loss, and anemia, it is less likely in this case due to the absence of lytic bone lesions (holes in the bones) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels). MM also typically presents with elevated IgG or IgA, not IgM.

 

Option C. Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS): MGUS is a benign condition where a small amount of monoclonal protein is present in the blood. It usually doesn't cause symptoms and wouldn't explain the patient's fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, or anemia.

 

Option D. Smoldering Multiple Myeloma (SMM): SMM is a precursor to multiple myeloma. While it shares some similarities with MM, it typically doesn't cause symptoms or organ damage. This patient's presentation with fatigue, weight loss, and blurred vision suggests a more active disease process than SMM.

 

Educational objective:

 

WM often presents with hyperviscosity symptoms and bone marrow infiltration by lymphoplasmacytic cells.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with WM presents with tingling and numbness in their extremities. Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-MAG antibodies

 

Option B:

 

Anti-MAG (myelin-associated glycoprotein) antibodies are associated with peripheral neuropathy in WM. Cold agglutinins can cause hemolytic anemia, while anti-cardiolipin antibodies and ANA are associated with autoimmune disorders like lupus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cold agglutinins: These antibodies are associated with cold agglutinin disease (CAD), a type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. While CAD can occur in WM, it typically presents with symptoms of anemia like fatigue and shortness of breath, not peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option C. Anti-cardiolipin antibodies: These antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, an autoimmune disorder that can cause blood clots. They are not typically associated with peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option D. Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA): ANAs are a group of antibodies that target components of the cell nucleus. They are commonly seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases, but not typically in WM-associated neuropathy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Peripheral neuropathy in WM is often associated with anti-MAG antibodies.

choices.text: Allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) from a matched related donor (MRD)
Allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) from an unrelated donor (MUD)
Allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) from umbilical cord blood (UCB)

questions.text: A patient with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in first remission is being evaluated for stem cell transplantation. Which of the following types of transplant is most likely to offer a graft-versus-tumor (GVT) effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) from a matched related donor (MRD)

 

Option B:

 

The graft-versus-tumor (GVT) effect is a unique feature of allo-SCT, where donor T cells recognize and eliminate residual leukemia cells. MRD allo-SCT is the most likely to offer this effect due to the closer immunological compatibility.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT): In ASCT, the patient receives their own stem cells, which have been previously collected and stored. Since the immune system recognizes these cells as "self," there is no GVT effect. ASCT is mainly used to allow for higher doses of chemotherapy.

 

Option C. Allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) from an unrelated donor (MUD): While MUD allo-SCT can also elicit a GVT effect, the risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is higher than with MRD transplants due to increased immunological disparity. GVHD is a serious complication where the donor's immune cells attack the recipient's tissues.

 

Option D. Allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) from umbilical cord blood (UCB): UCB transplants also have a GVT effect, but they are often associated with slower engraftment and a higher risk of infection compared to MRD or MUD transplants.

 

Educational objective:

 

Allo-SCT offers the advantage of a GVT effect, but also carries a higher risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

questions.text: A patient undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) develops a maculopapular rash, diarrhea, and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)

 

Option A:

 

The triad of skin rash, diarrhea, and elevated liver enzymes is characteristic of acute GVHD, a common complication of allo-SCT.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): While chronic GVHD can also affect the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and liver, it typically develops later after transplantation (months to years), and presents with different manifestations like skin thickening, dry eyes/mouth, and lung problems.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) reactivation: CMV reactivation is a common complication of allo-SCT, but it typically presents with fever, fatigue, and less specific gastrointestinal symptoms. It doesn't usually cause the characteristic skin rash seen in GVHD.

 

Option D. Engraftment syndrome: This is a non-infectious inflammatory syndrome that can occur shortly after transplant. It may present with fever, rash, and pulmonary edema, but it usually lacks the specific gastrointestinal symptoms of GVHD.

 

Educational objective:

 

Acute GVHD is a serious complication of allo-SCT and requires prompt diagnosis and treatment.
